source.name: CCIP Cross-Chain Token Transfer 1
source.instructions: A developer is building a decentralized application that requires transferring tokens from Ethereum to Avalanche. Which of the following statements about using Chainlink's Cross-Chain Interoperability Protocol (CCIP) for this purpose is correct?

answers.answer: CCIP can transfer the tokens, but cannot execute smart contract functions on the destination chain
CCIP can transfer the tokens and execute smart contract functions, but only on EVM-compatible chains
CCIP can transfer the tokens and execute smart contract functions across different blockchain networks, including between Ethereum and Avalanche
CCIP can only transfer messages (data) between chains, not tokens
CCIP requires the developer to implement their own security measures for cross-chain transfers

source.guidance: Chainlink's Cross-Chain Interoperability Protocol (CCIP) is designed to enable secure transfer of both tokens and messages (data) across different blockchain networks, including the ability to execute smart contract functions on the destination chain. It supports transfers between various blockchain networks, not limited to just EVM-compatible chains. CCIP can handle the transfer from Ethereum to Avalanche, executing necessary functions on both ends. Furthermore, CCIP comes with built-in security measures, leveraging Chainlink's proven oracle networks, so developers don't need to implement their own security for cross-chain transfers. The other options are incorrect as they either understate CCIP's capabilities or misrepresent its functionality.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT analyze and evaluate the capabilities and limitations of Chainlink's Cross-Chain Interoperability Protocol (CCIP) in facilitating cross-chain operations
